title: What do you buy when you're sad?
intro: Dan turns up in the studio with a load of shopping bags and a very strange outfit he bought to cheer himself up. You'll also learn some vocabulary related to shopping and mood.
this_week_question: Online shoppers in which country spend more per household than consumers in any other country, according to a report from the UK Cards Association?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: going shopping to make yourself feel better
bad feeling when a person realises they don't need or want the thing you've bought

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to Six Minute English. I'm Neil and joining me today is Dan – who is weighed down with shopping bags and wearing something very… strange. What's going on, Dan?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Hi everyone. Well, I was feeling a bit miserable so I decided to cheer myself up by going shopping!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well that's lucky because the link between shopping and mood is what we're looking at in this 6 Minute English – and of course we'll be giving you six mood and shopping-related vocabulary items. But first, our quiz:

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Norway seems to come top of lots of lists, so for that reason alone I'm going to say Norway.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: We'll find out at the end of the show. Now, Dan, you said just now that you went shopping because you were feeling down.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: That's right – I like a bit of retail therapy .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Retail therapy is a humorous expression which means going shopping to make yourself feel better.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Oh I do that all the time.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, I can see. And you're not alone. According to some research done by the website moneysupermarket.com, people are more likely to buy things they'll later regret when they're feeling sad, bored or stressed.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well I was feeling a bit down in the dumps . And that's a way of saying 'sad'.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh dear, Dan. Sorry to hear you've been down in the dumps . I only hope you don't also get a pang of regret about your purchases when you get them home – the research suggests that you will.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: A pang is a sharp pain. We often hear it used figuratively to talk about strong emotions like guilt, regret and remorse . You're making me feel worse, Neil

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Sorry Dan – it's all for educational purposes! Our audience will learn from your pain! Remorse is like regret – and there's a good expression to describe exactly that bad feeling you get when you realise you don't really need or want the thing you've bought. Buyer's remorse .

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: OK, OK, OK enough about me. Let's hear from Sam, Phil and Catherine from the Learning English team to see if their mood affects the shopping choices they make. Listen carefully. Can you hear the three types of things they say that they buy when they're down in the dumps ?

transcript.author: Insert
transcript.text: Sam Honestly, I tend to buy food. Anything that will bring me comfort, so it can be any sort of warm drink, hot drink but also anything kind of warm and cosy – so like a nice jumper.

transcript.author: Phil
transcript.text: Definitely, if I've had a bad day at work, or for whatever reason or I feel terrible, tired, I am more likely to buy something on the way home.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Oh when I'm feeling sad, I probably buy a little bit of wine and often something to wear. I find that a bit of retail therapy when I'm sad usually does the trick at the time, so it makes me feel better. But I do find that when I look in my wardrobe, the things that I bought when I was sad – I never wear them.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Sam, Phil and Catherine there from the BBC Learning English team talking about what kind of things they buy when they're feeling down. What were they?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Food, drink and clothes.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That's right. Sam mentioned she buys food, warm drinks and a nice jumper to keep her cosy . That's the feeling of being warm, comfortable and relaxed.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Catherine also mentioned drinks – this time wine. And she also said that buying clothes does the trick . That means achieves the result she intended. She feels down, she buys clothes, she feels better – it does the trick .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But what's interesting is that Catherine said she never wears the clothes she buys when she's feeling sad. That's exactly what the survey found – people regret the purchases they make when they're sad, bored or stressed.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Sounds like a case of buyer's remorse .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Indeed. Well, time now for the answer to our quiz question. I asked this: Online shoppers in which country spend more per household than consumers in any other country, according to a report from the UK Cards Association? Is it:

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I said b) Norway.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I'm afraid you might need to go and buy some more stuff to cheer you up – you're wrong! The correct answer is the UK. Apparently UK households spent the equivalent of $5,900 (£4,611) using payment cards online in 2015.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well, I hope they were happy when they made those purchases or they may feel the pang of regret I'm scared I might get after today's discussion!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, a good recap of the vocabulary from this programme might do the trick .

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Shall we start with the first word? Do you ever go in for a bit of retail therapy , Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Actually I try to avoid it. Especially after reading this survey – I don't think the happiness you feel after buying something lasts very long. In fact, you can end up feeling down in the dumps .

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Down in the dumps - meaning sad/unhappy. Yes and a pang of regret might follow once you realise you've spent a lot of money on something you don't really need.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: A pang is a stab – used here figuratively to mean a sharp pain used to talk about strong emotions. And after the pang can come buyer's remorse .

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Hmm, I'm beginning to feel buyer's remorse from this leopard skin onesie. Seemed like such a good idea at the time.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well it does look cozy – warm comfortable and relaxed, so I think if that's what you wanted, it does the trick .

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Does the trick , meaning achieves the result you wanted.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK before Dan heads off to buy even more stuff he doesn't need, please remember to check out our Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube pages.

transcript.author: Dan/Neil
transcript.text: Bye!
